So, I'm a historian and I constantly complain to my wife about the low quality of 'edu-tainment' available out there. You know what I'm talking about... some show with a guy wearing a fedora, with just the right amount of beard stubble [according to the focus group], and a weird name that is one part Biblical and another part Generic Celtic ['Jeremiah Brodie' or 'Dylan Zacharias' are two I use when joking about it] who acts like the most basic information on a subject is some stunning scientific revelation ['Did you know that the Pyramids of Egypt were built by (insert dramatic pause here) SLAVES ?']. The stuff is not only stupid but condescending and trite, and it drives me crazy.
This IS NOT that.
And I want to offer my congratulations on finding a great balance between being accessible to the average person and yet still informative. You can bet I'll be looking in to other offerings on your channel.

Just as an fyi, one of my college professors who specializes in plant science previously worked for a bank and he would constantly go to properties where people stoped paying to reclaim them
Sometimes there would be spills in the property ranging from oil to gasoline, and they can not legally do anything with the property until it is cleaned
He said that what they would do is release a special type of anorobic bacteria that would eat and decompose oil and gasoline.
This was in the 80’s

I grew up in La Brea so seeing this was an everyday thing for me . On weekends we'd go swimming in the pockets of the lake that held rain water , the sulphur in the water is good for your skin just DO NOT dive in with your eyes open....the same sulphur in the water burns your eyes (I learned this the hard way).
Years ago a man crossed it at night as a shortcut to go to another village, but he made the mistake of walking across what is called " the mother of the lake" which is the softest part of it.
They found him the next day , he sank down to his neck but was still alive .

There's a pitch lake somewhere in the Caribbean that hosts a population of guppies. Compared with guppies that live in the small streams that feed into the lake, resident guppies are free of external parasites.
